discourse_list.title: Uniswap already blocks 250 addresses to be \xe2\x80\x9claw-abiding\xe2\x80\x9d in the United States

content.content: Nation World News – 21 Aug 22    Uniswap Already Blocks 250 Addresses To Be "law-abiding" In The United States. Over 250 cryptocurrency wallet addresses were blocked on the Uniswap exchange, one of the most widely used in Ethereum, for allegedly being linked to illegal      It is the second time that Uniswap does something like this, this is good and bad, it is good because it cleans a little injustice (although we know that ironically the injustice that moves through the banks is much greater), and bad because we see that they are easily manipulated by the U.S., decentralization is over for Uniswap and other protocols that are taking similar measures. It seems that now it is time to make a fork of Uniswap that complies with the decentralization, since this in the future lends itself to sanction any address that does not comply with the “terms and conditions” at the convenience of the U.S. . Is there a possibility that in the future Maker can make its own DEX ?, the more self-sustainable we are the better, collaborative systems are good to some extent.
Yes I expect more to come as the space is very volatile and unsteady.

Now let’s see if I understand, we have more threats to our protocol and DAI, first Circle and DAI, then the tornado cash blockades (after this, the income of DAI mobiles increased) now the largest liquidity in a DEx that we have is wanted apply to regulatory laws, this would not already be a red alert?
Although not clear from the article, my understanding is that the dApp at app.uniswap.com is blocking the addresses, and not the smart contract itself. Though please correct me if I am wrong.
Yes, that’s right, Uniswap blocks addresses that are in the suspicious category to prevent any future U.S. sanctions.
Scariest part is that some blocked accounts are collateral damage. I.e. the balance is in regulators favor… Hope its the tailend of the TC sanctions

And even worse, the entities with the largest deposits in the staking contract are institutions that are likely to have to get on their knees before the regulators, this includes Lido finance, kraken, staked.us, stakefish, bitcoin suisse, among other institutions, together these cover more than 66% of the validators, which could give them the power to censor Ethereum at the protocol level. It is difficult for that to happen but it is not impossible to happen.

But this only blocks them from using the Uniswap frontend not the actual sc itself, just making it more tedious. The thing is that the front-end is technically a centralized entity. Even if Maker built another frontend, it would be subject to the same regulations from my knowledge.
I think we will see that, if some entity or government wants to significantly disturb the space, it can be done one way or the other.
